items.synopsis: Just 3 per cent of residents of the South Australian town of Quorn use their mains water. The rest, rely on bottled or tank water.

title.children: Flinders Ranges residents' 30-year battle to access drinkable tap water faces further hurdle

image.altText: State emergency vehicles near Streaky Bay.

items.synopsis: As the search for the body of a 55-year-old surfer believed to have been killed by a shark on South Australia's far west coast is postponed because of ocean conditions, a local resident tells of his encounter with a great white in the immediate aftermath of the attack.

title.children: Streaky Bay local saw great white the 'length of a sedan car' after suspected fatal shark attack

image.altText: A pair of regent parrots on a stick with slightly different colouring.

items.synopsis: The regent parrot population is suffering, but a group of researchers who specialise in working out what's wrong with rare and beautiful creatures could make the difference.

title.children: This beloved parrot is in decline in SA's Riverland. Enter the 'difficult-bird' research team

image.altText: A man dressed as Santa wearing a face mask.

title.children: Another 'COVID Christmas' on the cards thanks to fresh wave, experts warn

title.children: I was meant to be anonymous to my seven biological kids — but that's impossible today

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here in Jerusalem, we see missing posters for the hostages everywhere. Just down the road from the ABC's Jerusalem bureau is a handwritten sign strung up outside someone's house. In Hebrew it reads: "First, release the hostages." It's a sentiment shared by many people in Israel. Some families of the hostages say they would have preferred that Israel's government negotiates the release of their loved ones before escalating their ground incursion in Gaza. Among those missing are Tal and Adi Shoham, their son Naveh and daughter Yahel. Tal's dad Gilad Korngold says he trusts the Israeli army to make the right decisions, though three weeks into this crisis, he's struggling to hold onto hope. "There was a lot of hope. Now [there's] less. Every day with no signs from them, it's terrible," he said. A military liaison stays in regular contact with Gilad, but he says they came up with an arrangement that helps him get through the night without lying there waiting for the phone to ring. "He is coming three times a week to my house to talk to us, but we agreed that if something terrible happened, he will not call me up that night."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The families of the hostages say they're struggling to hold onto hope

children.content: Here in Jerusalem, we see missing posters for the hostages everywhere.

props.alt: A picture of a grey haired lady with "bring her home now!" written on it

children.content: A missing poster for hostage Adina Moshe.
(ABC News: Rebecca Armitage)
Just down the road from the ABC's Jerusalem bureau is a handwritten sign strung up outside someone's house. In Hebrew it reads: "First, release the hostages."
It's a sentiment shared by many people in Israel.
Some families of the hostages say they would have preferred that Israel's government negotiates the release of their loved ones before escalating their ground incursion in Gaza.
Among those missing are Tal and Adi Shoham, their son Naveh and daughter Yahel.

props.alt: A family sitting on a shoreline

children.content: The Shoham family are believed to be among the hostages held in Gaza.
(Supplied: Gilad Korngold)
Tal's dad Gilad Korngold says he trusts the Israeli army to make the right decisions, though three weeks into this crisis, he's struggling to hold onto hope.
"There was a lot of hope. Now [there's] less. Every day with no signs from them, it's terrible," he said.
A military liaison stays in regular contact with Gilad, but he says they came up with an arrangement that helps him get through the night without lying there waiting for the phone to ring.
"He is coming three times a week to my house to talk to us, but we agreed that if something terrible happened, he will not call me up that night."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has told ABC Radio Melbourne innocent civilians should not pay for the horrors perpetrated by Hamas as Israel exercises its right to defend itself. “That is why we have international law and international principles of engagement in conflict. We would continue to publicly assert that Israel should abide by these,” she said. “We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life. There are ongoing civilian deaths … you’ve seen the international response. The reality is the international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths. “So when friends like Australia urge Israel to exercise restraint and protect civilian lives it is really critical that Israel listens." Pressed on whether she would condemn Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp, which the United Nations Human Rights Office has expressed could amount to war crimes, Senator Wong reiterated Australia’s position is to urge Israel to protect civilian lives and observe international law. “We want you to exercise restraint because this matters for those innocent civilians who should not be paying for those atrocities of Hamas who does not represent the Palestinian people,” she said. Wong says the Australian government is supporting those families and Australian citizens who got out overnight, and will keep working to ensure they get as many Australians out as possible.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong says 'international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths'

children.content: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong.
(ABC News: Adam Kennedy)
Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has told ABC Radio Melbourne innocent civilians should not pay for the horrors perpetrated by Hamas as Israel exercises its right to defend itself.
“That is why we have international law and international principles of engagement in conflict. We would continue to publicly assert that Israel should abide by these,” she said.

“We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life. There are ongoing civilian deaths … you’ve seen the international response. The reality is the international community won’t accept ongoing civilian deaths.
“So when friends like Australia urge Israel to exercise restraint and protect civilian lives it is really critical that Israel listens."
Pressed on whether she would condemn Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp, which the
United Nations Human Rights Office has expressed could amount to war crimes,
Senator Wong reiterated Australia’s position is to urge Israel to protect civilian lives and observe international law.
“We want you to exercise restraint because this matters for those innocent civilians who should not be paying for those atrocities of Hamas who does not represent the Palestinian people,” she said.
Wong says the Australian government is supporting those families and Australian citizens who got out overnight, and will
keep working to ensure they get as many Australians out as possible.

title.children: ASX higher amid increasing market confidence that the US Fed has finished hiking rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking of property, last night on The Business I took a look at the latest CoreLogic Home Value Index - aka national house price data. Nationally the price we're paying for a home rose 0.9 per cent in October - but with another interest rate hike potentially days away, we might start to see a slowdown. Have a look at my story below for more.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: House prices are a couple of weeks away from hitting a new high

featuredLink.title: Why national house prices are heading towards a historic high | The Business | ABC News

children.content: Speaking of property, last night on
The Business
I took a look at the latest
CoreLogic Home Value Index
- aka national house price data.
Nationally the price we're paying for a home rose 0.9 per cent in October - but with
another interest rate hike potentially days away
, we might start to see a slowdown.
Have a look at my story below for more.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There were 4,282 loans issued for the construction or purchase of new homes in September, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Lending in that category over the last three months is 27.7per cent lower than the same quarter last year. The Housing Industry Association's senior economist, Tom Devitt blames the Reserve Bank's interest rate hiking cycle. "Lending activity has been weighed down by the fastest increase in interest rates in a generation. This is drying up the pipeline of new home building work across the country." He warns it means there will be fewer new housing starts next year. "There are very long lags in this cycle due to the record high volume of building work that was in the pipeline when the RBA first raised rates in May 2022. The volume of houses under construction only started declining in the June quarter of 2023, and remains elevated, a year after the first increase in the cash rate. "This large volume of building work has obscured the impact of these rate rises on the broader economy, especially unemployment, as the building industry employs over one million Australians." Mr Devitt ended with this warning: "This slowdown in lending for new housing will make it increasingly difficult to reach the Australian government's target of building 1.2 million new homes in five years."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lending for new homes at 20-year low - effects will be felt next year

He warns it means there will be fewer new housing starts next year.

"There are very long lags in this cycle due to the record high volume of building work that was in the pipeline when the RBA first raised rates in May 2022. "This large volume of building work has obscured the impact of these rate rises on the broader economy, especially unemployment, as the building industry employs over one million Australians."
Mr Devitt ended with this warning:
"This slowdown in lending for new housing will make it increasingly difficult to reach the Australian government's target of building 1.2 million new homes in five years."
